38929012.review:
It's brilliant at what it does. An authentic, fluid experience that is a genuinely amazing recreation of table tennis in VR.
But seriously, don't do what I did and buy this thinking you're getting a fun little game. This is a balls to the wall table tennis simulator, and table tennis is no quirky playground game. It's actually very difficult. I've unfortunately had to refund as I literally cannot play this game for shit, nor do I really have the width required to effectively maneuver around the table when needed. But I recommend it to those who can do it well.

38843096.review: This is a great game if you like table tennis and I think it accurately recreates the experience of playing it. I play this on a Rift and would recommend a fairly large play area. I have a moderate play area and the game is very playable but I worry that some short or wide shots may cause me to run into something. With saying that, the game does allow you to position the table for the best fit for your situation or preference, but I prefer to have a slightly larger view of the table for the realism. This game allows you to volley the ball around for practice or play a match against a selectable bot ranging from amateuer to legendary. There are a few mini games included which are challenging. This game also includes online multiplayer with matchmaking which seemed to work fine for me but I only played it online once so far. Overall, If you enjoy table tennis in real life then you should enjoy this game.

38838083.review:
I never imagined a VR table tennis game would be much good, but this is brilliant. The physics are very believeable and after just a few test games to get used to the feel, I find it utterly convincing. 

I played table tennis for my school many, many years ago, but haven't really tried since - mostly due to a lack of space TBH. I was amazed to find that my muscles still remembered how to play after 30+ years, and almost everything that works in reality works in the game. Spin is spot-on as far as I can tell. Only downside is not having a physical table to smash when you're annoyed with a bad shot - I found that out the hard way and have the head wound to prove it.

AI seems pretty decent too. The Amateur level is great for beginners. I can generally beat the Semi-Pro most times. The Pro level wipes the floor with me - I can barely score a point! And there's two more levels after that. I'm sure I'll get better, but it's nice to have a challenging AI. There's a lot of people playing online apparently, but given that I'm actually pretty rubbish, I'll leave them to it until I can hold my own a little better.

One of the best things is that the Vive controller weighs about the same as a paddle, which really aids the immersion unlike many other VR games. Also makes for a pretty good work-out. After 20 games or so, I'm really building up a sweat! The big plus to that is that I don't have to share my Vive, 'cause no-one wants my cold sweat on their forehead. 

Only real negative is the music, which is not bad per se, just gets very repetative very quickly, but easy to turn it off. Almost makes me wonder why they even bothered.

Picked this up in the sale, but it's well worth full price if you fancy a wee bit o' ping pong.

38831391.review:

38681743.review:
Une affaire ! Si vous êtes déjà équipé en matos VR, acheter ce jeu vous permettra d'économiser le prix de raquettes et d'une table de ping-pong, d'un abonnement en club et d'un entraineur particulier.

Il s'avère que le tennis de table se prête particulièrement bien à la VR du fait des dimensions de l'aire de jeu qui sont compatibles avec la VR à l'échelle d'une pièce d'une taille raisonnable. Il n'y a ici pas de déplacement artificiel : tous les mouvements sont réstitués 1 pour 1. La physique du jeu est de surcroit extrêment crédible. A vrai dire je ne connais pas de simulation sportive plus fidèle à la réalité.

Le mode online fonctionne bien sans pour autant faire de miracle au niveau de la compensation du lag. J'ai ainsi pu faire connaissance et jouer avec de parfaits inconnus situés dans d'autres pays à des heures avancées de la nuit. La transmission fidèle des gestes et de la voix sont évidemment de la partie.

Fondamentalement, ça reste du ping-pong sans fioritures : si vous aimez dans la vraie vie, vous aimerez certainement jouer à 11TTVR, sinon probablement pas.

38222677.review: Table tennis is the perfect game/sports for room-scale VR. It simply feels like playing ping pong for real. 38150556.review:
This is my favourite VR game by far (otherwise I probably wouldn't have played 100 hours so far). 
I got it for about 5€ when it was still called PongWaves, and the merging with Eleven made it so much better. 

If you love table tennis, as I do, and can't be bothered to use a real table when its 3ºC outside, this is as close as it gets. 
I haven't tried Paddle Up or the new Oculus game, but here's the thing. I don't think I really need to.

I wasn't really a fan of the new environments, considering how long it took to finally see them. I think the lighting scheme in all of them makes the ball harder to see, probably due to shadow contrast.

If I had a request for this game, it would be adding a game option to make rallies more epic, such as the ball leaving marks or particles on the table the closer you hit to the lines, or increasingly noticeable effects the longer the rally becomes. Not very realistic, but it would certainly be fun.

Pros
- The physics are great
- Music is pleasant
- The haptic feedback is perfect and feels real, try balancing the ball on the bat and you'll see exactly what I mean
- There is plenty of customisation that can be done in the menus
- I always manage to find people in multiplayer (Maximum I've ever waited is 10 minutes and you have an AI you can play against while waiting so its no big deal).

After trying Racket Fury, Paddle Up and Eleven, this game is for me the best by far!  
The options to modify your hand on the paddle, ball spin, the table, etc., it makes this game easily playable in so many situations (even SEATED!).  
I demo this a lot and even people that do not know how to play, have a lot of fun.  
Also, training (against AI or the ball machine) is top-notch! The different levels of AI difficulty are very good and the ball machine was pre-recorded training exercises (but you can also make your own!), which helps a lot to train or just warm up for some online play.  
  
Personally, I haven't played nor feel the need to play a single match online, simply because I like to relax and have some fun, but also because I feel I'm not yet ready to face real players.  
  
I'm still in the process of buying my first VR games and this is definitely a must-buy for anyone who enjoys table tennis (even if you suck at it, like me!)

35885350.review:
Pros:
- Very accurate tracking and physics, which is impressive and makes the experience so enjoyable.
- So much customizations and options, you can really adjust it to your preferences. Height and position of the table, color of the ball and table, how you hold the paddle etc.
- Very stable and nice multiplayer. It's so much fun against other people. Every match I played with others we were laughing, chatting and having crazy exchanges. 
- The community! Relaxed, no flaming, often pretty skilled.
- It plays like real table tennis. You cannot achieve more with this kind of game.
- Nice graphics and stages. Stunning attention to detail: You can even shoot the ball out of the windows or use the walls.
- Only 20 €!

Cons:
- Singleplayer is fine with matches against the AI and highly customizable training options. But a little league, tournaments, progression, unlockable content etc. would be awesome. But I think it is too much to ask for considering it's not a 60 € game.
- You need a lot of space. My playing area is 2,2 m x 1,5m and I hit my couch a couple of times :)
- VR is still not mainstream, so you sometimes play against people from the other side of the globe. Such a fast game needs low pings.

Conclusion:
Buy it, it's awesome. The most fun I've had with VR so far!

34771770.review:
Amazing game, very realistic physics, plays just like the real thing. My go-to game whenever I play VR.

Some possible future improvements:

-- Tournaments, ladders, leagues, trophies (maybe with a custom trophy cabinet in that displays in your play area when you're the host?). The games are really fun, but very disposable without competitions.
-- More environments, especially cozy interior ones like the loft (though a school gym would be good)
-- A wider selection of background music. The single song that plays can get annoying. Ability to play your own music library through the environment's speakers would be perfect.
-- An optional lobby area where you can mess around with other players while waiting for a game (instead of just playing the AI) if you want to. A way to invite those players to games, or add them as friends, would also be good.

I hope the dev keeps supporting this with new updates

+ Great physics, graphics and customization
+ Many levels of AI player (and their great animations)
+ Multiplayer - even a year after release, there are still active players looking for match

- Bots' play feels too simple and unnatural - they fail in covering certain areas but got almost every ball in center; also when they hit ball, it never miss table, which is most of point-losses made my human players

• Stable internet connection required for multiplayer - since it is a very fast-paced game even slight delay in connection between players has a huge impact on smooth gameplay; for me, it was usually very laggy

34454217.review:
The enviroments, tables, paddles, it all feels like you're actually in the room playing table tennis, and you'll work up a sweat playing it.
The mechanics are spot on, the paddles move flawlessly with 1 to 1 tracking, the ball's physics are spot on, it's seriously like you're playing the game.
There are several fun mini-games, apparently with more in the works, along with a full co-op feature and several single player championships to play through.
Had I tried a demo of this, I would have easily thrown $50 at it, at $9.99 it's a steal.
I played with the Rift, 2 touch controllers, an i7700k pc with a 1080gtx and everything ran perfectly in ultra high resolution mode (you can see the grain of the paddles, it's uncanny).
Just be patient with the initial setup, make sure you have the space allotted properly, you can adjust the position and table height with the left touch controller, and it's also used to access the menus and serve the ball.
But all in all, if you like Table Tennis, it's an absolute must have, and the wow factor is amazing.

My personal number one wish is to have tournaments, both for singel- and multiplayer. The AI needs to be tuned somewhat as well. We would like to have some additional scenery etc. But the very tentative Developers, especially our "fav" Hillary "the guy" :-) is always listening to the community, very forthcoming and handles all requests, questions and feedback with the outermost respect. As you can read in other reviews the game itself is really good. 
BUT buyer beware.  
If you, like me, mostly enjoy the multiplayer, it can be nearly impossible to get a match outside of peak hours. 
 
Sometimes when playing outside of peak hours I will get matched with the same person over and over again, problem is that he is probably from NA and I'm in EU, so the ping is at 140ms making it impossible to react to 90% of the returns. Ping compensation has not helped here, no matter what setting it's on. You will, most of the times, lose the point even before the ball hits your half after a return.
 
But I will still recommend it as it IS  really an awesome game, and multiplayer in peak hours is a blast. 
8/10

As a noob IRL table tennis player, it's hard to find any major flaws with this game! It feel so much like the real thing, it's silly! I make all the same mistakes as I do IRL, and I have the same strengths and weaknesses. 

I started out embarrasingly rusty and sucky, but managed to beat semi-pro AI fairly consistenly after an hours worth of practice. 

You can adjust table height simply by grabbing the table and moving it, and you can adjust bat angle in correlation to your controller by holding down grip and rotating the controller - super intuitive way to find the perfect settings instead of silly sliders and what not.

Only complaint is that I get the odd frame drop here and there, which is strange with my hardware. (2600K@4.8, 8 GB ram@2133/10-11-10-24, Geforce 1080ti)

An absolute must buy for anyone who likes table tennis..  hell, at this price give it a shot even if you've never played table tennis before - you might like it, and if you get good at this game, you'll gain IRL skills for sure!

I played it using Rift and Touch controllers.

33963017.review:
GUYS this is THE BEST GAME EVER MADE. 15/10 All the way!

This is THE FIRST Review I've ever written.

(PRO-TIPS: ANITICPATE where the ball will hit... As soon as the opponent hits... your motion of swinging the paddle should be 15% through, when the ball is over the net 60%... and as soon as the ball hits your side of the table, have your paddle swinging right in position at 100%.. Doing this is the best tip I've found. Do it faster and at a forward down angle and you can reflect some super fast curve balls just barely over the net. SO MUCH FUN!

HOLD THE TOP OF THE CONTROLLER with your pointer finger spread along the bottom of the donut thing.. This helps much more for me than holding like a bat or whatever at the bottom.)

Add me and let's play. Let me know if you have any tips as well!

Go ahead and buy it, then continue reading... First off, you wouldn't think just a simple ping pong game could change your life but, this gives me something to do, AND ENJOY... everyday after a hard days work standing on my feet...

The learning curve is absolutely perfect. Every match you start to hone your skill bettter and better. Every degree, angle, direction you swing... every speed, return, serve.... It's all so pleasantly detailed.

If you're looking for an inexpensive game to play over and over and over... that isn't all out balls to the wall taxing like Space Pirate or Racket NX or whatever... This is it. PURE PING PONG...

You can literally play 3 hours without getting tired. I like to goof off a couple rounds on Semi-Pro to try and see what kind of curve balls and super serves I can pull off... Most likely I lose those matches like 3-11... Then I'll play with what I think is 'safe'... and I'll get like 9-11...

It's hard for me to play perfect games cuz I like to goof off. It's just so Damn Fun! But I think I've won like 8 out of 100 games. I've played for ~29 hours and really learned a lot.

I'm putting my PRO TIP at the top of this so it helps people. I promise I'm going to play more competitively and serious. I want to start a league. Some people with 300+ hours are awesome to play with. They wipe the floor with me, but I still win a few.

My next goal is to finally beat Professional Level. Being able to replay is stellar! Very surreal being able to wtch yourself, behind yourself.. Another tip is to 'push' through the ball like your hitting a punching bag.. this puts a lot of spin on it and helps you with your front hand hits. Get good at back hand and front hand hits and you can actually keep the ball on the table for like 100 back-and-forth hits.

The update has brought many new customizable options.. YET there are alos a couple bugs here and there. Sometimes it hits on the table but I don't get the point. Sometimes I miss the return but swear I should have hit it.

Carrot is an amazing and passionate developer.  He showed me how to download beta and wants us to have a great game.

BUY IT NOW. ADD ME. SEND ME AN INVITE! PEACE

Hello everyone, this is my first VR-Review, so here goes!

VR Table Tennis fells like the real deal, like you are actually playing table tennis, and that is the most
important thing to me!
Since the lateest update you can play on 5 different envirements, change the Skin of your paddle, and change the mask of your player avatar.

There are 3 Main modes in the game, Singleplayer, Multiplayer and Minigames.
The Minigames consist of stuff like target practics etc.
Singleplayer allows you to play a set to 11 points against the Computer, comes in 5 different difficulties, and as a beginneer Amateuer is already quite hard!

Multiplayer allows you to either play against a friend or a search for a random person.

Sometimes it can be quite laggy when the other person is from far away, anything about 100ms is quite hard to deal with since the ball just appears in front of you.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
If you like Table tennis, buy this! At 10 bucks this is a steal, if you see this on a sale, buy it without thinking about it!
For this price its unbeatable, but dont expect anything else then Table Tennis

33348224.review:
While it is lacking certain things that the devs have promised, they are all aesthetic/fluff features that would just make the game look more polished. 

Other than that, the game is the ultimate table tennis simulator out at the moment. The physics are convincing and extremely precise, I'd say about 99% of the time, any other fault could be attributed to reprojection or netcode. 

The AI is fantastic to play against. It's just about as good as playing against an actual person. I don't play past semi-pro personally because it gets way too hard after that but I'm not a great player by any means.

Multiplayer population, as with all VR games, is lacking but if you have patience you can usually get into a game. If not, the AI seems to be a perfectly good substitute aside from the whole 'not-talking-robot' thing.

$10 is a fair price for it but I would wait until a sale at this point since it's so old and doesn't get updates much (dev has been busy with psvr port)

31898774.review: Most (flat screen) screenshots for VR games are very deceptive. Deceptive in the fact that they cannot begin to capture the immersive experience. This game is a perfect example of this... You look at the screenshot and get the impression the game is very mediocre. I bought it, put my headset on, WOW. For the price, this is a very well put together game. The visuals are very appealing, not only that, the game dynamics are phenomenal. I got exactly what I was after, a fun and entertaining workout. This is almost as close to the real game as you're going to get - kudos to the devs. I'm far from a pro table tennis player and could be wrong, but I've played a few games and this just felt right. My only gripe is that you must hold the Oculus touch controller a bit weirdly to get the bat at the right angle. Maybe a setting to angle the bat would be good so that it fits "naturally" in your hand. Not that a touch controller will ever feel like a bat. Overall - this is one of the best value games I purchased to date for my Rift – and I have a big library of games. If you're in two minds about purchasing it, there's no need for that, you'll be very pleasantly surprised. Go ahead and buy it, you'll have no regrets.

31510284.review:
I found this game after playing VR Ping Pong, realising how suited Table Tennis is to VR. 
Eleven lacks the charm and the tournament of VR Ping Pong, but beats it in almost every other department.

Very realisitc physics: It's not one to one, smashing doesn't seem to accelerate the ball half as fast as real life, and spins are not 100% but it's all pretty darn close.

Graphics: Very nice looking, but most importantly smooth! Full hand and face animations from the AI add a lot to the realism and strategy. It really feels like I am playing against a human.

There is work to be done though. The game has everythng in place for a AAA style table tennis game, it just lacks content (which seems to me to be the easy part). E.g. A tournament mode, and a couple of different looking AI Player faces, so it feels like you're playing against different opponents and it could be a top fully fleshed game.

As is it, well worthy of the £6 it cost, and the price should get hiked once new content is released. 
Thanks for the fun Devs!

31475702.review:
Simply the best and most accurate table tennis VR game out there! This is probably the game I play the most and my favorite VR game on the Vive! The AI is excellent and human-like including some trash-talking gestures :) The multi-player feature is awesome and I've enjoyed playing people from all over the world. 

However, it does have some bugs and lacking features which I hope get fixed soon!

Bugs/Issues:
- During multiplayer, the ball can sometimes get ... lost .. and you have to end the match. 
- During the quick-game Waves, the ball-shooter can shoot the ball into the net which stalls the game.
- Multiplayer starts abruptly, and this results in someone getting a point prematurely. It also messes up the service order.

Suggestions:
- More spin action! Feels like I'm playing with a recreational paddle even with Spin setting at max!
- When AI chops the ball, it has little if no back-spin and it's misleading. 
- AI after Professional Level does unrealistic super-chops. You don't see this in real life. Either top-spin offensive matches or real chop defensive play with back-spin.
- More environments, please! I'm really getting tired of the same studio room.
- Different avatars? Bunnies are cool and all, but, getting old.
- A Reset button for when something goes bad and the game isn't tracking play.
- Multiplayer selection - it would be nice to see the list of online players and their location/ping. Sometimes multiplayer keeps selecting the same person to play. I'm sure it's trying to be smart, best select, but, I want more control.
- Global rankings (I know, it's on the to-do/coming-soon list)

31463801.review:
So you've got a shiny new VR headset...and you're quickly discovering there is a phenomal bunch of games that are clones of each other and generally not very good, even the good ones have reivews where people have played only literal minutes - you need something in your library that you can go back to for fun every now and then that ticks all the right boxes of what VR is supposed to be.

Fortunately, you've found it.

This is one of the best VR games you can get, it has fantastic physics, excellent AI, simple controls, and limited look down / up moments requiring headset fiddling, and while it has room scale - the excellent rapid positioning means you can use it in very limited spaces.

Honestly, of all the VR games I've got and have tried, this is the one I keep coming back to for a few minutes when I start a VR session, and it's great to set up a few challenges with friends when you've got people around.

30991941.review:
This game originally sold me on the premise of fun virtual table tennis, but it did not follow through with intuitive and enjoyable gameplay. 

When I was dropped into the room with the table, despite the presence of a menu button label, there was no clear indication as to how to begin my serve (hint: it's the trigger button). 

Within my ten minutes of trying to play, there were numerous instances where I attempted to hit the ball as it was about to go past my right side, but I couldn't actually strike it despite quickly placing my paddle in the path of the ball flying through the air. This is something that I can do easily enough in reality, but not so much in virtual reality.

My frustration with the game only increased in the extra modes against red, spherical bots. There was absolutely no pause between my failures to strike the oddly high-angled bot serve and the bot's next serve, resulting in a very quick game over in the Waves mode. The Zones mode asked me to hit particular zones on the opponent's side of the net, but these exceedingly rapid, odd-angled serves didn't allow for any chance to hit the ball ... or the next one ... or the last one, resulting in that swift game over. 

Maybe I'm just a poor table tennis player, but I won't be sharpening my skills in "Eleven: Table Tennis VR".
I feel like table tennis in Rec Room might be more my speed.

This game is absolutely fantastic. I've probably spent more time playing this than all other VR experiences combined, and I'm not even a fan of table tennis :)  The physics is remarkably spot on, with spins and everything, and there is a very nice haptic feedback in the controller, too. AI is pretty good to offer a variety of challenges. Multiplayer mode is unfortunately greatly hindered internet connection speed (not a developers' fault) and makes the game practically unplayable in that mode.
Interestingly enough, since I suck at table tennis, I looked for some tips online on how to improve game. I applied these real-life tips (ranging from the focus on the leg movement to paying attention to improve backhand control) to a VR game and it worked great: I quickly managed to improve a level and then two of the AI. I wonder if these VR gains improved my real-life game: something I will try soon.
Apart from trying to somehow improve multiplayer, I can only wish for more superficial stuff: more environments, more tables types, stuff like that.

Magicians at work is what we have here.  

Couple that with a bombin' and bumpin' soundtrack (read: "song" -- it's also a shame you can't use your own music library atm), some sweet digs to play in, and a complete multiplayer experience (some audio and video lag have been very common so far, but I've only logged a couple hours -- it's possible I've just gotten really bad luck) and you have a very good VR release backed by developers who appear to have developed a regular cadence for updating the game and listening to players.  Great work all around.

29861947.review:
Out of all the games in the Oculus and Steam stores, this game along with Rec Room is my most played. Probably because it (by far) surpasses any other attempt at mimicking an actual real-life activity in a video game. This game FEELS like actual table tennis on a very precise level, and this is also why it is constantly challenging. Lots of things can be improved of course, like:

- Ranked multiplayer instead of just random, and/or save preferred players
- More AI variation - the Semi Pro and Pro are two very different beasts :)
- Better keeping up with rules, e.g I've gotten away with net serves many times. Also I reckon the need to avoid getting hit by the ball in real table tennis? I.e. an overshot ball need to miss the opponent as well as the table in order to count as a point for the opponent. This could get abused though.
- More polish in both game and menus. The ultimate would be a "multiplayer arena" with multiple tables, where you can play and get up the ranks (physically by moving up tables!), or just watch and cheer on others playing. Also maybe Oculus avatar support?
-More players! Maybe this game needs better promotion. I find it incredible that Oculus (or Valve) have not pushed this game since it beats out their own "AAA" titles in pure gameplay,

There are so many things that could make the experience even better than it's current state, but that said - this is still THE killer app for VR this far in. Now come at me with those n00b smash serves! ;)

As a single player game, I really enjoyed this - the controls feel really intuitive; just pick up the bat and play.  The AI is also good fun to play against, and at the higher levels is extremely tough to beat.  

The multi player side however sucks.  I regularly had to wait 10 mins plus for anyone else to appear as there just aren't enough players using this game for the match-making to work.  This isn't the fault of the developer; just a limitation of the size of the player base in VR at the moment.  Even when there is someone else there though, the lag makes the game almost unplayable as the ball jerks about, vanishing from view then reappearing as it crosses the net; for a fast paced game like this that relies on players reading the motion of the ball and opposing player, it just doesn't work.

The bottom line though is that the game is worth the money just for the single player - buy it.

I have played many games in VR and some are good but mostly they feel short and you get tired quickly. I haven´t played this one much, but I believe I have to write a review because it´s one of the best VR experiences I have had with the HTC Vive. I played a lot of table tennis before so I knew exactly what to expect and to my surprise, this feels like you were actually playing Table Tennis in real life. The controls feels exactly like a Paddle, it´s really amazing. I started to play with an amateur AI and he did made some stupid mistakes, but if you start to play well, the AI starts to play better. After a while, I played with a Pro and whoaw, it´s the third level in the list of 6 in how hard it is, and let me tell you, it´s hard but so good. He did effects and I´m almost sure I manage to do some effects too but you really have to work hard to do it well, because it´s very realistic (it´s been ages since I played). But depending on how you hit the ball and how hard, the balls reacts like a real ball, it´s really, REALLY realistic.

And the feel of the ball, oh, let me tell you about it. I started to play with the paddle and the ball trying to do some equilibrium and I felt the control vibrate every time I touched the ball, like a real paddle!!! I don´t know about the oculus controls but people say they feel great. Well, the Vive controls feel exactly like if you had a paddle in your hand, you just use it EXACTLY like a paddle. And what´s best, you can adjust the position of the table, to the sides, to front or back, to higher or lower, wherever you like, until it´s in the best position. I don´t have much space in my room, like 1,50 x 1,50 if much, I believe lower than that, but as you can move the table, you can adjust very small spaces to play and move without concerning you will hit something.

As other reviewer said, buy it only if you like Table tennis, because is that, table Tennis. I haven´t played more because I have back problems so I got a backache the next day, but I just didn´t want to stop, is that good. The mini games are great also, mini games like hit a target with a ball is thrown to you, hit a particular place of the table, hit balls that come from diferente positions and heights. Multiplayer? I don´t know, I didn´t use it so no idea, and you don´t need it, there are levels for the complete beginner to the pros, I didn´t try the hardest because the pro (that as I said was the third one in level of 6 levels)kick my ass everytime.

29049110.review:
So good! My personal killer app for VR! 

The physics are excellent, and the gameplay makes excellent use of 180 degree roomscale setups. I'm playing this with a 2-sensor Oculus Rift setup with 2m x 1.5m play area, which is the minimum recommended area. This is my favorite VR title so far because the gameplay is fun and seems to have a high skill ceiling. Fortunately, lots of VR awkwardness is mitigated thanks simply to the fact that it's table tennis. You don't really have to worry about getting tied in knots, losing trackig due to rotation, or locomotion.

Couple of notes that might help:

1) If you're using an Oculus Rift, you may start the game with the floor at eye-level. You can fix this by repositioning the table, but you can also just run SteamVR setup, which should configure your height correctly.

2) You might need to reposition the table so the edge of the table would be touching your virtual thighs. By default, the table edge seems to be at the front-edge of your play area. That means if you reach in to swing at a ball, you might put your hand through your computer monitor or something. I think serious players stand back quite a bit, but at least on lower difficulty levels, the AI hits short balls often, so you'll often find yourself needing to make swings that are right over the table.

3) You'll want to configure your physical-to-virtual control mapping and it's not totally obvious how to do this. Go into settings and then look down at your paddle hand, and you will see that you can adjust paddle position. Wish more games did this!

4) It actually took me a little while to figure out that you need to squeeze the trigger of your non-paddle hand to spawn a ball so you can serve. I sat in front of the table staring at my AI opponent for longer than I'd like to admit.

Looking forward to the additional environments!

28794988.review:
[h1]Unlikely killer-app and true "eSports"[/h1]

Disclaimer:
[list][*]Played with Oculus Rift + Touch, 2-front-facing camera setup
[*]I like table tennis in RL. If you don't, this game may not be for you.[/list]

Before buying this game, I tried VR Sports Challenge from the Touch pre-order bonus. This was fun for 1-2 hours, but never felt like real sports. My expectation when buying Eleven Table Tennis: just another tech demo with unintuitive controls and assists that make every shot magically hit the target. 

But, what a pleasant surprise: The controller is just a paddle! The buttons have no function. [b]The only control is to swing your paddle against the ball[/b]. There are no assists. This is pure physics, the real thing. To make such a direct, raw control scheme is brave because it requires perfect tracking and perfect physics. And to my tremendous delight, both are spot-on. The tracking shows how marvelous the Oculus Touch tracking works (judging from reports of other players, the Vive tracking works equally well). The physics can only be credited to the fantastic work of the developers. Ball and paddle physics are nearly perfect. All kind of spins work as expected. If there are differences to the real world, they are subtle enough to only be noticed by very experienced players.

As a sport, [b]Table tennis is a perfect fit[/b] to the current generation VR headsets. It requires little room and is played front-facing with minimal movement on the spot. The paddle has comparable size and weight to the motion controller. The ball is small and light enough to make the controller haptics feel realistic. While the player moves his whole body, all movement culminates in the force applied to the paddle and therefore it is adequate to only track the hands.

As a result, [b] this game skips the uncanny valley and goes directly to holodeck.[/b] After finding the right settings (which is a bit troublesome, see below), the game feels just like playing real table tennis. As someone who likes playing in real life, I can immediately use the play style I already know. And I notice making the same errors.

[u]Single Player mode[/u]

The setting is a stylish apartment with the ping pong table in the middle. In the left hand you see the Oculus Touch model, in the right hand the paddle. You have no body or arms. The opponent is shown the same way, plus a (somewhat scary) mask for the head that conveys which way he is looking. Each game is basically one set (11 points). The basic rules are enforced by the game.

In Singleplayer mode, you play against a surprisingly good and natural AI of several difficuly levels. On the higher levels, the AI starts to apply spin and play faster balls.

Additionally there are a few Practice Minigames. For example, in one you must return balls to specific corridors. This game mode as a lot of potential to turn it into a more useful training tool, but feels quite limited at the moment.

[u]Multi Player mode[/u]

In Multiplayer mode, you can play against a (Steam) friend or random player.

A critical point here is the connection quality, especially the ping. In most cases, this worked surprisingly well for me. If the connection is good, there is no noticable difference to the Singleplayer mode. If it is bad, the ball "jumps" a bit after the opponent hits, making it harder to react. While the game does everything it can to smooth that out, above a certain lag threshold, the game becomes unplayable.

Unfortunately, there is no ranking system yet. Still, to be able to play table tennis against players from all over the world as if in the same room is magical and tremendously fun. The game has voice chat activated by default. Laughing together on funny balls or praising nice shots makes the experience even better (of course not all player use their microphone or speak the same language).

[u]Settings[/u]

The most important setting I had to change was the paddle position. For Oculus Touch, the default position is unfortunately tilted. I adjusted it so that when keeping my hand vertically the paddle is also vertically, like a continuation of my hand. The Rift's nose gap is very useful here to AR-like see your own hand and the paddle at the same time.

Also there are some settings related to the paddle. I imagine it to be like the choice of the physical rubber properties of the paddle. You can experminent and adjust those to your liking.

[u]Wish list for the developers[/u]

The raw gameplay is in place and extremly fun. But I think there is a lot of potential to make this game even better. If the developers are reading this, here are my top three wishes:

[olist][*] Better Match making: Introduce rankings (visible or hidden). It is no fun for either side if the gap in play strength is big. Also check the connection quality and do not match players if it is too bad.
[*] Simplify the settings and provide better default values. Oculus Touch paddle position is tilted, use the correct rotation as default. Instead of sliders give some beginner friendly choices for paddles. Hide the sliders in advanced settings.
[*] Bring the game to Oculus Home to reach more Oculus players (Cross-play with Steam!).[/olist]

[u]Conclusion[/u]

Table tennis is a uniquely suited sports for VR. Eleven Table Tennis provides an incredibly realistic simulation of an olympic sports making it arguably the first true "eSports". The Multi Player mode on top of the raw, but near-perfect gameplay provides endless replayability.

This is the VR game I come back to daily. The physics are so satisfying and well done, this is a great game to just jump into for 20 minutes. Features are somewhat bare-bones, but I trust that a lot of things should be added in the future. I would however like to see updates come a bit more frequently

A few things should be addressed:
- There is an awful glitch where the ball falls through the floor in multiplayer. There is no way to reset the game, so you need to exit the match and restart. It really screws up the flow of the game.
- A more gradual increase in AI difficulty. I have over 20 hours in this game and I can barely ever beat semi-pro.
- More environments are said to be on the horizon, I can't wait for that. The ability for user generated backgrounds would be great as well.
- More efficient matchmaking. I sometimes sit around for 10 minutes before I get matched with somebody.

For these shortcomings, I still can't recommend this game enough. Nothing matches it for replayability on the vive. It's so simple, but so immersive.

28339122.review:
This is a pretty great ping pong game in terms of the touch on the ball. I was using this with oculus touch controllers, and while I did have to rotate the grip on the control to orient the paddle correctly, it worked really well.

I play ping pong recreationally in my office, last year I think I played everyday on my lunch break. I was able to start playing this game immediatly and start making all the same errors I do in real life. Everything feels right, down to the spin and power on the ball. 

The AI levels are pretty good, though the jump from amature to semi pro feels too steep, and the legendary AI is not screwing around, which is great.

I'm not too happy with the audio on the ball bounces and contact, but this could be improved in the future. There was also no feedback on the touch controllers, not sure if this applies to vive, but either way it could really use a very gentle buzz depending on the type of contact with the ball so you can start having some slight physical feedback.

I played only one multiplayer match, but it was too laggy to really play well. The problem here is the game seems to force correct the balls position through the latency, so you can expect the ball to warp around a lot, making play almost impossible. This may not be the case with a better connection though, I saw no ping indicators so I had no way of judging whether that one game was an outlier or not.

I also found out how sturd the touch controllers were. The AI gave me a nice high loft that was begging to be spiked back down, and I did, right into my desk shelf. I knocked a chunk of wood off the desk and drew blood, touch controllers in tact, ping pong ball on the floor.

 10/10 would bleed again.

28333172.review:
Wow!  I am absolutely blown away by how fun and realistic this is.  I don't really think it could be much better.  I have over 40 games for my Vive and even though it's such a simple concept, this is my favorite.  I have played A LOT of table tennis over the years, and actually competed in some pretty big competitions at an Ivy League school with players from around the world, and this game is SPOT ON!  Just wow.  I want to share a few improvements/suggestions only because I'm such a big fan, that I want the options to continue to evolve (please!).  Do not take these as too critical, as my overall rating on this game is 10/10, A+++.  

1.  There seems to be an issue during "waves" mini-game, that the ball is mistakenly shot into the net or off the table and there is no way to retrieve the ball.  It's easy to abandon that game and start a new one, but a bit annoying, and maybe fixable?  It would be frustrating if this happened during a record-breaking run!  

2.  I'd love to see high-scores for the mini-games, even if just local scores.  Most of us are very competitive and want to have high scores to beat or compete with others in our household.

3.  Add another vote to the "locked" table height, using the floor calibration to determine and set.  As many of us are sticklers for consistency, it would be nice to know the height is the same every time.

4.  Any way to have a multiplayer lobby?  Maybe even a self-rating of sorts that could indicate which level you've beaten within the game to separate players?

***5.  And most importantly (unless I missed a setting), can you add a setting of matches to 21 points?  Especially for multiplayer?  And even consider adding a Best of 3, Best of 5 option?  Prior to 2001, games to 21 were the normal, and some of us still like to casually play that way, even if it's not the International standard any longer.  

Again, KUDOS!  I absolutely love the gameplay and I can't stop telling all of my friends about how much fun and realistic your game is!

27573249.review: Wow!  Really incredible game.  Once you tweak the settings around for a while (paddle position / power / spin), it feels almost *exactly* like real ping pong.  I'd recommend the power and spin sliders set to about 1/4 of the max value.  When setting the paddle position relative to the controller, try to line up the palm face of the handle to the palm surface of the controller (top surface underneath the menu button).  I found that mating these two surfaces was critical to emulate the real feel.  If the surface of the controller is at any other angle or position, hitting the ball just feels off.  I was expecting latency to kill multiplayer, but they correct for it pretty well.  Real life ping pong skills transfer 1:1 in the game no matter how janky you hit your shots.  Topspin, backspin, sidespin, and even hitting off the edge of the paddle!

I own 50 VR titles and I play this game the most.

Physics so real I feel like I'm actually playing ping pong. The only other vr ping pong  I've tried is Paddle Up, and this game has the clear edge on realism.

I almost want to vote this down, because my one big complaint is the multiplayer. I've had a few incredible matches with people where there was very little lag, and matched quickly. HOWEVER, the normal experience has been to wait for 20 mins not matching with anyone, and only being able to rally with a painfully easy AI. A few lag crashes too. 

DEVELOPER RECOMMENDATION: Since we have to wait so long in multiplayer queue sometimes, please make it so we can do single player matches and skills games without losing our spot in queue.

Single player gameplay

I find the AI to be an incredible opponent. I started off not particularly skilled. The lowest difficulty got me good at basic ball control, and now I'm having epic over hand smash rallies on the third difficulty level. Levels 4 and 5 are basically Insanity and Asian. Every shot is a wildly spinning bullet. But more and more I'm returning shots. All flukes for now, but it's happening more often. I would bet that playing this game is getting me good a real life ping pong.

I've played a fair amount of ping pong in my day and I'll just say that they've nailed it.  I wasn't expecting much even after reading all the great reviews but I have been highly impressed with this game.

Take some time to play with the settings to get the "feel" right and you'll be rewarded with an excellent experience.  I found the initial settings to be off for me personally as it was taking far too much power to get the ball over the net and I wasn't getting the spin I'm used to getting.  I played around with the settings for a few matches and after about 15-20 minutes I settlted on something that feels super realistic to me.  

A word of caution though... be careful while playing.  I lunged for a ball that the AI had hit into the net and my brain was expecting to be able to use the "table" to brace myself from falling over.  Well... I guess you see where this is going.  Made me laugh and feel stupid at the same time but I think this is just another testatment to how immersive and awesome thsi game is.

If you even like ping pong a LITTLE bit, get this game.

26248880.review:
Eleven: Table Tennis VR is, without a doubt, the king of all VR table tennis simulations and beats all other VR ping pong alternatives hands-down! The in-game physics is incredibly accurate to the extent that it makes me forget that I'm playing it in VR. The developers have been working really hard on it, regularly tweaking the physics and adding new features, listening to and communicating with us constantly via social media, and even consulted professional table tennis players to improve the physics.

Before the latest improvements were added, my other favorite was Paddle Up. But after the devs had added the recent improvements, Eleven Table Tennis VR has now become the only table tennis game that I can recommend confidently with my eyes closed and label it as a 'must-have' if mind-blowing realism and accurate physics are what you are after. 

This is the first game I launch when I first start up my Vive everyday, even though I've played it for more than 5 hours already. Several gameplay features have been added recently, and numerous bugs have been fixed. The devs have also informed me that they are already working on adding more environments. Multiplayer (with voice, of course) had little to no lag, and I've played with several other players online without any problem whatsoever. 

The only thing I dislike a little about the game at the moment is the default environment, which looks a bit gloomy for my taste. Hopefully some different ones will be available soon.

In conclusion, if you have even a passing interest in table tennis and own a Vive but still haven't bought this game, you have absolutely no idea what you are missing out on. Do yourself a favor and get the game. Also, check out the 'Replay' feature that has been added recently and thank me later! 

On a scale of 1 to 10, Eleven: Table Tennis VR easily earns a 9.5 from me! Thank you devs for all the hard work you have put into this project for us.

25950173.review:
I've been playing ping pong for most of my life, playing almost daily for a few years a while back (purely on a casual hobby level, though), and this game lets me do almost all I could do in real life. 

Other VR ping pong simulations I have tried may offer more game modes, but the tables feel like playing cheap all-weather tables you might find in public parks. "Eleven: Table Tennis VR" feels like playing with a high quality bat on a tournament table. The multiplayer mode is great fun and I have played against players from all over the world (USA, Spain, Sweden, England, Germany, you name it). While there are still some bugs to be squashed and fine-tuning to be made, it is already an awesome experience and the developers are extremely helpful, responsive and eager to constantly improve this excellent game.

Without any exaggeration, for me, this game alone justifies the pretty hefty investment the HTC Vive is (including new computer parts to make VR run more smoothly). I'm really looking forward to all the future features yet to come!

Wow this latest update rocks, the physics is almost perfect now, i do the same errors i usually do on the real table.
i had purchased paddle up and ping pong vr too and before this update paddle up had the best physics.
In paddle up on its side it's easier to do curved shots, but i've just seen in the options they have added a couple of fader to tune the paddle speed and spin, nice.
Multiplayer is ok and it looks it handle latency a bit better than paddle up, i have played with a 100ms ping opponent and it was somewhat playable, obviously not perfect but there's not much they can do with that latency, anything above 40 ms produces visible latency and probably going over 100ms gives unexpected behaviours, the key is how they handle it.

EDIT: Played again with a 95 ms opponent in california (i'm in italy) the match was very smooth to be honest, i didn't expected so much quality with a so far connection.
i've lost a couple of points where i was sure i did it right, but we played several matches and the overall experience was great.

So for the guys that have problems with multiplayer they have probably packet loss due to other factors, like other people using the connection, other programs inside the computer using bandwidth, a low or disturbed wifi signal in case of wifi, or some nodes over the net that have problems (saturated dslam or node for example), if connections are smooth, game is smooth.

Remember to serve FAR from the table, if you serve over the table you will lose the point ( i think it's a real table tennis rule)

25656702.review:
(Comments here are directed at the 09-22-2016 update.)
Having tried this latest update, I have to say I prefer the previous version. Perhaps I just need time to adjust to the new physics. Though I'd still recommend the game, it feels like it's taken a step back.
While the increase in difficulty is welcome (even Legendary was cake before), and the introduction of the announcer is nice, there are many new detractors:
   -The new supposed emphasis on spin seems to have been overdone with respect to back spin while at the same time nearly eliminating the effects of side spin (it's almost impossible to curve the ball like I used to--and can in reality--with a sideways backhand). Back spin is now so strong that the computer opponent often sends serves that appear to travel (and arc) in slow motion (very strange) and die when they hit my side of the table.
   -The ball seems heavier now in a way that feels unrealistic. More shots end up in the net, yet still if I try to put any real power behind a hit the ball almost invariably ends up going too far. The computer opponent now has no trouble blasting the ball, though (which is nice).
   -I've had several occasions where I'll return a ball and it'll disappear mid-air above the net, pause a second, reappear seemingly stationary against the computer opponent's paddle and then get fired back at me as if the computer returned it without any of that ever happening.
   -Were the spawn points in Waves always such highly reflective red chrome? Because Waves was always such a short experience I didn't play it much before. With this update having Infinite Waves, though, I'd like to play it more, but the spawn globes are terribly distracting (a softer matte color and smaller spawning spheres would improve this). Also, the globes are often very high above the table. Like, Magic Johnson reaching up over his head high. Seems a little ridiclulous (and doesn't make for good practice since in-game shots will pretty much never come from those locations).
   -Sometimes on serves, the loss-of-point buzzer will sound the moment my paddle hits the ball even though the serve goes through cleanly and within the rules/bounds. This also happens to the computer opponent (though less frequently).
   -Lastly, in spite of having a beefy system (i7-6700k, 32GB RAM, GTX1070, SSD), I'm getting much more sporatic graphical stuttering than in previous versions (this comes in the form of minute pauses, particularly just after the ball leaves a paddle).

25647712.review:
Managed to get one of the 100 free copy's that where given away by devs to celebrate the merging of Ping Pong Waves and Eleven Table Tennis.

When I saw this game I was hoping for a playable Ping Pong game. I recived more than I thought I would get for sure. Not only is it playable but it's also really fun and the multiplayer works great.

It's still early access and some bugs are around that are a bit annoying now and then but Multiplayer is amazing. Even when playing with an American while being in Sweden I noticed no delay issues. 80-90 ping without even noticing an issue, that's some impressive stuff.

[h1]Posetives:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Physics that work almost always as you would expect. This will most likely become better with time but it's "good enough" for now :)
[*]Multiplayer that works suprisingly well even with a ping of 90 ms.
[*]AI that feels really human (A bit to human perhaps with some annoying (time consuming) reactions)
[/list]

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Hard to tell why you lose your point sometimes (Pretty sure it's when paddle touches table most of the time)
[/list]

[h1]Suggestions: (For devs)[/h1]
[list]
[*]Add in some info for when you lose a point for non usual reasons. For example if you lose your point because you hit your table you should be told so.
[*]Make your non paddle controller vibrate if it's your turn to serve.
[*]In Waves mode don't have time between shots be depandant on when your ball gets counted as pass or fail. This results in it being advantagous to do high balls to get dead time between shots and fails result in faster balls towards you which easily starts a "fail train".
[/list]

25170360.review:
It's table tennis, pure and simple. The game puts you in front of the table, you pick up the bat and ball, and you are playing. It seems quite close to the real thing. The main drawback is the controller feels different to a table tennis bat handle, but it passes for one quite well, especially if you go into the options and angle the bat to your preference. 

At the time of review, the game is still in early access. As such, I think the AI needs a bit more development. The computer opponent seems to find it impossible to counter shots close to the edge of the table, but has no problem with ones close to the net. Who wins is determined by whether you ace your own serves or fail to return the AI's. The computer opponent is almost infallible in its ability to keep the ball on the table, even on the easiest difficulty setting. Of course, multiplayer adds the element of spontaneity missing from single player mode, but I lost patience waiting for a human opponent after only a few seconds because there's nothing else to do while waiting. You can't even throw ping-pong balls out of the open window. Trailing wires and lack of space made moving quickly to the left and right a bit risky for me and so I spent the whole game rooted to the spot.

I have to say, this is a really good use of VR and I think this has the makings of a great game. Even in early access, it's very good. As someone who enjoys table tennis, I can say it is about as close as I can imagine table tennis simulations getting without a table tennis bat shaped controller.

24983413.review:
I've played table tennis actively for 10+ years (I was once anihilated by Jan-Ove Waldner in Sweeden), and for me this is the most immersive and near to life VR game on HTC Vive so far! The game settings allows you to adjust the table position, height and the racket angle (I prefer to set in the middle with the HTC Vive controller) - which are all important for the gameplay. The first 30 minutes I could not manage to play an agressive game, but had to play safe with blocks, backspin and counter-loops. Drop shots positioned on the short left and right on the table felt very real, and I really got to put my table tennis experience and reactions to use, last millisecond wrist turns to save the ball was very true to life. Being able to change colour of the table was nice, the graphics are much nicer then any other table tennis game out there. Another reviewer had a nice tip to press Shift when starting the game and select Beautiful graphics.

After some time I also got the hang of the drives and managed to play a more agressive game on both forehand and backhand by using actual table tennis techniques (but a bit slowed down from real life). It took some time before owning the legendary 1-player opponent, but I managed at last and worked up a good sweat. This game feels like the real thing! 

A couple of things can be improved. For example when serving an ace, no point is given but I have to serve again. Spin don't seem to have very much effect on the game. It would be nice to be able to adjust the amount of backspin in a serve or stroke according to speed of movement and point where the ball hits the racket, but maybe the players just need to get some more expensive rubbers or glue up the racket before the game :) Also the training robot could have a forhand / backhand & letter practice mode.

Looking forward to following this game and to finding any other players in the multiplayer section! It would be awesome to have a online table tennis league.

This game is absolutely brilliant! (If you like table tennis)

It's still early days and there's clearly room for improvement (it's "early access"), but as it stands it's very, very playable.

At 5 Euros it is great value for money.

If you launch it with the shift button pressed, you can choose the desktop resolution (this doesn't affect the VR resolution, just takes some of the strain off your gfx card) and also choose the game graphics quality. You can choose between: Fastest, Fast, Simple, Good & Beautiful. It runs fine on beautiful with my R9 290X & Phenom II 1045T @ 3.2GHz.

If you like table tennis, you're going to come back again and again to this simulator.

Good points:

Nice graphics
Good ball movement with different spin effects.
Don't need to bend down to pick up the ball 8)
Different levels of difficulty
It's a lot of fun.

Possible improvements:

Better multiplayer support
Tournaments with NPCs (playing more than one match)
Different bat holding options (you can only alter the angle at which you hold the bat, but no pen grip option yet)
Higher level NPCs should be able to do a smash (I've yet to see one take advantage of a high ball, even on legendary)

Keep up the good work!

Just a quick note. This is probably really obvious, but it wasn't to me! Duh! 

I started off holding the bat as I would normally hold the controller. I think your're supposed to hold it with the haptic trackpad to your palm and your index finger on the controller ring. This way, the bat is in the right position and you get the haptic feedback every time you hit the ball.

It would also be great to see the score when you finish playing, as I'm usually too engrossed to look at the scoreboard and then suddenly the match is over and I don't know what the final score was. It would be cool if the NPCs had names or something too, that way it would be more emotionally involving when you beat them.

24687661.review:
Firstly, WHERE IS THE DOOR IN THE LOFT? AM I TRAPPED PLAYING PING PONG FOREVER? haha

Having played both Ping Pong VR experiences on Steam, this one is easily the best. Very realistic environment. The physics are almost spot on, and allowed me to do fast, pro shots with what almost felt like top-spin. The other game felt like a cheap gimmick compared to this.

Haptic feedback on the vive controllers are pretty good but could be better. If Valve can make a bow & arrow feel realistic then hopefully this dev can do the same with a ping pong bat :) Either way, the other ping pong game does not have haptic feedback at all, so this is much better!

The difficulty levels of the AI are great, I managed to have a tough point-for-point match on the World Class difficulty (and I get smashed on the difficulty above it, 'Legendary'). I imagine even better players than I may want harder difficulties though.

The AI bat needs some swing animation when hitting the ball to make it feel a bit more realistic.

The environment is nice, the music is calming, the bed has been slept in. I am genuinely excited for more environments, say on top of a city skyscraper at night? The views would be fantastic and I would love to smash ping pong balls off the edge of a building and not worry about consequences!

I attempted the Multiplayer component briefly, but a Windows Firewall prompt appeared on my Desktop and I wasn't aware of it in the VR headset. Only found out after stopping the game that that was why it wasn't working. I am sure it will work now that I have clicked Allow on the prompt.

8.5/10, will play this for hours.

I am glad of having tried this game. I remember playing ping pong at high school, like 20 years ago or so. Always wanted to buy my own table, but none of the flats I've lived were big enough. Also, I don't have any friends to play against with, so having my own table didn't make sense anyway.
Ok, so this game kills both problems for less than £10.
I was kinda afraid that the physics or the ball behaviour could be off, but it only took me a few matches to release that I was doing the same strategies, body motion and literally, playing the same than when I played in the real world.
The only thing I am missing is having something to do while I'm waiting for someone to join to an online match. The game keeps me waiting doing nothing. Apart from that, this is a must have. Specially at this price!

So far my review it's been about describing how is it like playing ping pong in VR, but that is something other ping pong games can give you.
After September  2016's update this game has become the best one for me. The improvements they've put has all it needs.
I have to be honest and say I was trying another ping pong game that has more configuration options, game modes and it's multiplayer seemed to work better, but after this update I've requested a refund for that other game.

I hope that these guys keeps improving this game the way they've done this time.
Yeah, I am missing some more locations, ball colors, avatar customization and perhaps more game options/fun, but it's a matter of time and I won't refuse a game with a solid fundations like this one. 100% recommended

24623127.review:
Always wanted a ping pong table, bought this on sale after reading reviews of those available on steam for vive, so now I have one.

With Pong Waves VR unlike the table I would have had, I don't have to keep a clear space in the garage, unfold the table when I want to play, find the bats and at least one ball without a dent in it, then coerce a member of the family into playing.

Then during play, I don't have to keep wandering about getting the ball back from under the table or from behind the garden tools.

The controller implimentation is very good, the method of ball holding and release feels natural and makes it easy to either drop or loft the ball for different serve styles.

The game is reasonably configurable, I like that you can adjust the bat angle, change the colour of the table, turn down the "muzak". I also like that you can apply spins and the ball behaves pretty much as I expected it to.

I have not played the game for that long yet, but found that the feel, sound  and speed were good enough to fool me into believing I was actually playing table tennis like I have in the past.

Starting on amatuer I quickly changed to semi-pro and was having some gentle rallies after just a few games.

If you own a vive then, for good gameplay and the money this is a bargain ( even more so while on sale ).

24560973.review:
Ich bin kein Tischtennisspieler aber habe schon viele Stunden in Parks, auf Schulhöfen etc gespielt. 
Das Spiel kommt der Erfahrung des Ping Pong Spiel so nah wie nur möglich.

Die Grafik ist fotorealistisch. 
In einem Photogrametisch erfassten Loft mit vorgerenderten Lichtverhältnissen, spielt man im Singleplayer mit verschiedenen Schwierigkeitsgraden, einen WaveMode und ganz neu MULTIPLAYER.
Die einzig nicht statischen Objekte sind Schläger, Ball und die Maske deines Gegners (Multiplayer).
Der Winkel des Schlägers lässt sich übers Menü schnell ändern, bis der Controller genau so wie ein Schläger gehalten werden kann.
Die Physik wirkt noch etwas unausgereift, aber nach 4-5 Schlägen hat man den Dreh raus.

Der Multiplayer ist wirklich noch Alpha, was sich besonders an den teils starken Lags in den Games zeigt. Jedoch hat ich bei einem kurzen Test schon 2-3 wirklich sehr nette Gegner mit denen ich ein paar spannende Matches spiele konnte.
Das Mikro wird voll unterstüzt und ermöglicht einfache Kommunikation mit seinem Gegenüber.

Wie bereits der gesagt, der Multiplayer ist noch sehr stark im Alphastadium und sollte im Moment noch nicht ernsthaft genutzt werden, zum Reinschnuppern ist es aber schon sehr spassig und zeigt wohin das Spiel in Zukunft geht. 
Gerade eben gab es schon das nächste Update. Der Entwickler scheint im guten Tempo Patches zu programmieren.

24534481.review:
It's table tennis, you might think that it's a money grab for new users to VR. Something to fulfull the current void of titles, a bit like the iPhone app rush when they first came out. You'd be wrong though, as luckily I was since I thought it looked polished enough that it might be good and I'd give it a go.

It's excellent, and probably one of the first experiences I'll show others. Since almost everyone has played and understands table tennis, they can immediately relate to the experience and how accurately it matches real table tennis.

The physics aren't absolutely spot on but they're close enough that you really won't notice unless you like catching it out. I noticed when I took a ball and bounced it on a paddle and let it slowly lose energy until it sits on the bat. There's a small noticable jump from bouncing to resting on the bat. There's also a lack of being able to front/back/side spin the ball which I really hope is added.

I'm being picky though and being that this is in VR it's these details that are suddenly more obvious than on a 2d monitor.

One thing: I'd love to see a 'free practice' mode where the serving rules are less strict as it took a little while to understand why we kept getting fouls when serving (you have to hit the ball forward on to your side first straight away, don't bounce it on the table first before hitting over the net). I guess I just didn't know the rules so that's my fault overall. I feel it would help new users and letting friends/family get a rally going without becoming confused.

If you have a Vive and have played table tennis then this is a must buy in my opinion.

24505546.review:
[i] Before the review starts I am aware the game is still in Early Access. [/i]

Ping Pong Waves VR is a really true testament to Ping Pong in real life! The Physics in this game are so much better than other Ping Pong Games avaiable on the Vive. So far as of [i] 7/24/16 [/i] there are only two game modes, Waves and Single Matches. I will also go in depth in the Graphics of the game and in depth in the Game Modes!

[h1] Waves [/h1]

Waves is a arcadish type game mode that challenges you to hit balls the computer throws at you. This sounds really cool in theory, and it kind of is! However this mode only last for about 1 minute and then it's over.

[h1] Here are some tips to make this game mode better: [/h1]

[list]
    [*]Make additional levels
    [*]Make an Endless Wave Mode
    [*]Make a mode where both hands act as paddles so both have to hit incoming balls
[/list]

[h1] Single Matches [/h1]

Single Matches in this game are really what shines in Ping Pong Waves VR. There is lots of Opponent AI difficulties as well! From Ametuer to Legendary this mode will cater to veteran Ping Pong players as well as beginners. This game mode stays true to official Ping Pong rules and is really addicting. I was going to suggest what would make this game mode better but this mode is already good!

[h1] Graphics/Looks of the game [/h1]

The Graphics/Looks of the game is still what reminds me this game is still in early development. Don't get me wrong it doesn't look bad but it still looks like it's a placeholder or something along those lines. The look is very realistic where you are placed in what looks like a Apartment and it's feels really cool to be playing Ping Pong in a place you wouldn't ever play in. there are some weird Graphical Things I will mention now.

[list]
    [*]The Ping Pong Buckets Ping Pong Balls are shadeless and look kind of weird.
    [*]Most of the TableTop Colors are really bright and can't see any detail on the table with the Black option.
    [*]The overall lighting feels very plasticy and basic.
[/list]

Overall Ping Pong Waves VR is a very promising title and one I will keep coming back to! I would definitely reccomend people who like Ping Pong or people who haven't ever played a Match in their life! However now I want to give some things I would love to see get implemented into the game in the future!

[list]
    [*]A One hand serve option.
    [*]More modes. (Tourney Mode, Practice, Multiplayer, ect.)
    [*]More enviroments. (The Moon, A Rooftop, An Office Building, ect.)
    [*]More realistic lighting.
    [*]Make the net on the table Physics based.
    [*]Make the enviroments interactible, so you can hit objects and it interacts.
[/list]

That's all I could think of. Hope development goes smooth!

My review is going to be "harsh" because I am trying to give ideas for improvements. The game is actually very good with a lot of things done right.

It took me a while to translate my real world skill to the VR game. Topspin (hitting the ball angled over the ball) seems to be very challenging with the orientation of the controller and in game detection. I couldn't figure out how to consistently put spin on the ball aside from on a serve. (Such as a horizontal or vertical chop when hitting the ball back).

Improvements:
Real ping pong competition rules. Have to serve behind the table (I can reach over real far and hit the ball from right near the net). To serve, the ball must be thrown 16cm into the air and hit from the air. Implement service lets.
One more AI level, one that hits the ball close to you. Currently, even Legendary AI hits the ball and it lands halfway on my side. I can play standing at the table to hit everything back - this is unrealistic.

Great job by the developer. I'm looking forward to multiplayer.

The last update was a huge improvement on the physics. It's making progress but still has a ways to go. I sometimes get weird backspin characteristics vs the opponent, where they hit it and it bounces almost straight up (even when they didn't apply backspin). Also getting a good forehand top spin slice is touchy and difficult, it will often shoot somewhere in the room.

This has much potential, and if you're a Ping Pong enthusiast I'd get it once it gets some more features. For example, it doesn't detect a let on a serve, and you can't change the angle of the paddle in your hand so you have to kinda hold the controller awkwardly if you want to change the angle.

24263016.review:
Experienced ping pong player here (I've played and won a couple tournaments).

Pong Waves VR is not perfect, not yet. But it is not that far off. After an adjustment period, this feels like playing ping pong. 

CONS:
-Really hard top spin is making the ball go farther down in the air than it should. Makes a lot of your all-out slam shots hit the net until you adjust for the crazy amount of top spin. Could this be fixed with some sort of cap on the spin? Good luck fixing it. haha

-Most shots just don't feel like they're going high/far enough, overall. I'm not sure what would cause that, but an experienced ping pong player will easily notice. 

-No multiplayer. IMO, adding this (along with a ranking system eventually) could be interesting, because people who don't have a ping pong table could compete in a game that is truly not that far off from an IRL ping pong game.

PROS:
-Shitloads of fun. I have a ping pong table in my basement, but rarely have people to play against. This is a great alternative (I'm worried about it affect my IRL ping pong game. I feel I will be able to kinda switch my brain back easily, but this is yet to be seen. Will update after I play some actual ping poing!)

-Spin feels pretty damn great. I was pleasantly surprised that for most of my shots, even with complex slice/ cuts with diagonal back spin, the ball acts accordingly. The harder your shot, though, the less accurate it tends to be. Some spins can become very exagerrated because of a really hard cut. 

I know there are fewer pros, but I implore you to look at the weight of the pros. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is possibly jonesin for some ping pong.

PS:
stoked for multiplayer. I think it would dramatically increase the gameplay quality, along with a ranking system to feel that legitimate improvement.

PPS:
If you usually place your index finger on the backhand-side of your paddle, DO THIS in Pong Waves VR. It will greatly help your insticts. This being said, I feel the paddle should be very slightly lowered in the grip. Compare x)the location of your finger being on the back of a real paddle with y) the percieved location of your index finger on the back of the in-game paddle. Seems just barely high. 

TL;DR:
I am the Forrest Gump now.

24016122.review:
I have been playing table tennis for a couple of years; just enough to have a solid feel of the game. Naturally, my biggest concern for this game was how accurate the physics would be. I was hesitant to purchase this game when I read through the negative reviews, partly written by allegedly skilled real life table tennis players. In contrast, there are plenty of positive reviews claiming that the physics was spot-on. My first guess was that those were written by casual players, and this proved to be partly true when I finally played the game myself.

The first couple of minutes are mind-blowing, the feeling of presence is very strong. This feeling lasts until you unconsciously try to spin the ball in situations you would normally do in real life: it doesn't work, the paddle isn't very sticky at all. This is by no means immersion-breaking but a subtle reminder that you're still playing a game. Aside from the spin, there are some other aspects that don't feel 100% right like the force applied to the ball relative to your swing, affecting the trajectory.

But this is some next-level nitpicking and I'm sure many players out there won't even notice. For 5 bucks this is a title I can absolutely recommend. It's so much fun!

23993847.review:
Pros:
     - Physics are almost perfect
     - AI is fun to play against, and the difficulty levels scale up nicely
     - Environment is detailed, homey, and overall pretty immersive
     - It costs $5, so the cons are mostly mitigated, but I think it will be helpful to list them anyway
Cons:
     - My no.1 complaint is that the serving mechanic lends me to smacking my Vive controllers together (although some people may serve in a way that does not do this).  Part of the problem comes from the natural ergonomics of the Vive wands, but I feel like there are alternative possibilities to get around this.
     - Physics do not include spin (as far as I can tell)
     - No multiplayer

If you are into Ping Pong, this game is 100% worth the $5, unless you are waiting out on another App.  I listed "No multiplayer" as a con, but I'm not sure that is really fair at a $5 price point.  What I really mean is that I would rather have bought this game at a higher price point with multiplayer included, as multiplayer is such a naturally desirable feature of a VR Ping Pong game.
