23906263.review:
Background/Context: My name is Anthony and I am a casual gamer. My favorite games of all time for PC (in no particular order and off the top of my head)  are Diablo 2, Witcher 3, Skyrim, Heroes of Might and Magic, Might and Magic, BF2,and  Mass Effect (all of them). I mention this to give you some insight into the type of gamer I am to give you some perspective on my reviews. At the time of this review, I am a 30 year old white-male. I don't intend the 'white-male' part to change; but who knows. I have been playing table tennis since I was 5. Onto the review for Pong Waves.

Prior to the most recent update, I would not recommend. The backhand, my primary weapon, was not even remotely close to realistic. With this most recent update, this game is MUCH closer and I can recommend with some warning -- it is not perfect. It will frustrate you when you mentally know you've hit a solid shot, but it doesn't respond that way. With this most recent update, I would say that 80% of my shots feel realistic. That is good enough for now, for me to enjoy myself and have a spirited game against the AI, or in 'Wave' Mode.

AI: The first two difficulties are a cake-walk. The last one, is beastly. I haven't beaten the best setting yet -- "World Class", I think. You can easily exploit the first two settings with serves that they will never return. That is a bummer. Once you get to the most difficult setting, it is like you can't get anything past it. This isn't a bad thing per se, but I would like to see some better balancing on the AI

Wave Mode: Although this is OK, it needs some more content. It is currently setup in a manner where you get 'x' number of balls and you get 100 pts for each that you land on the other side of the table. That's it. I think they need to add an endless mode with a 'strike system'. Three, five, and seven (hard, medium, easy -- respectively?) maybe? Then add a leaderboard. Maybe a progressively more difficult endless mode? Starts of super easy, then progressively gets ridiculous -- sudden death style. 

Additional modes: Should be an "accuracy mode". Maybe there are rings you have to hit the ball through? Or targets, or something. 

Different Environments: Self explanatory

RPG Elements to add: Add different paddles with different stats that can be unlocked as you level up. Maybe you get stat points as you level up and can augment the following player stats: Power, Accuracy, Spin, others? Maybe add some accessories that you can win in tournaments to augment your stats. Very simple RPG elements would put this game over the top.

Playing Against Real Players: Add this feature with the above RPG features and create classes of tournaments: Bronze for players level 1-5, silver for players 6-10, gold for 11-15, etc. That would be a good time. 

Out of 5, I would give this a 3 right now, with the potential to be a solid 5 if they implement some elements that increase replayability, immersion, and engagement. I recommend this game as it is the only, and thus, the best pong game on the market.

23756719.review:
This game has several issues which make it not worth the purchase, even at a $5 price tag.

1. Serving.  The serve mechanics are extremely awkward with the ball attached to the same controller as the paddle.  This makes it very difficult to serve.  The ball should be in the other hand so you can have the paddle in any position and orientation you choose at the time the ball launches.

2. Multiple balls on the table.  if a ball goes in the net, it is not removed before the next ball starts into play.  This can get very distracting.  Hearing multiple ball bounces makes it more difficult to guage speed and timing.

3. Spin.  I am very surprised that there are positive reviews that comment on how great the spin mechanics are.  I would be surprised if spin is accounted for at all.  I am a very experienced ping pong player and I was never able to impart any spin on the ball.  Quite the opposite, it seemed to me as if the balls motion was very dumb, only using the orientation of the paddle to determine a reflection angle.  This meant every top spin shot went straight down into the table, every backspin shot popped straight up and attempts to slice side spin were fruitless.

If you are just interested in a very basic demo and you are a novice player who just likes to pop the ball up a little onto the other side of the table, this game will work fine for you.  But if you are looking for a simulation of actual ping pong, this game is not there yet.

39045563.review:
USING AN HTC VIVE

After only an hour playing, I've had all the ups and downs of playing table tennis, only this time virtually. The closeness to real life table tennis is extremely good and very surreal standing in my tiny office playing on a full sized table tennis table. 

Physics are very good although takes some getting used to when trying to apply the same shots you would in real life. I'd suggest leaving the bat speed and spin at default until your used to not actually holding your bat, then definitely tweak to your liking/real life bat (I had to reduce the ball speed and increase the spin to match my real life bat).

As I play traditional grip, I had some difficulties getting used to holding the vive controller in the same way I would a paddle, and actually got very frustrated that I couldn't do the same forehand shots as I would in real life, thinking this was the games fault. Once I readjusted the settings as mentioned above it became significantly easier and is just a matter of getting used to the virtual paddle. Would love to see support for vive trackers that you could attach to a paddle for even better simulation!

UI wise, very simple but not a fan of the bright primary colours, would prefer a more polished/clean look. Some graphical settings including AA and Super Sampling which is nice. Probably doesn't need many more considering the nature of the game.

Intuitiveness of the control scheme is very nice and like the fact you can adjust the table position, height and rotation to fit within your chaperone bounds, as well as being able to rotate the paddle to your liking.

The maps are nice, although the desert map seems not so well optimised compared to the studio (can't say about the other 4 or so since I haven't played them yet). Maybe some customisation options in the future and even a tournament style map?

The mini games are fun although could do with the same tweak settings that the "return practice" game does, would also like to see a go and restart button so you're not thrown straight in unprepared and so you're not booted back to the menu  after a few seconds when you suck as much as I do (the initial settings are too fast! :P)

What's also really nice is the fact the game shows a third person "table view" on your monitor so other people can watch you play!

Overall, well worth the money and can see my self playing this a hell of a lot when I can't get to a table as it's the next best thing!

38961383.review:
To write a review for this game, I have to seperate my feelings for table tennis (the actual sport) and Eleven, the table tennis simulator. I absolutely hate table tennis IRL, mostly because I'm just awful. Like, iredeemably bad. I can't win a round of table tennis against even the least skilled of my friends, and that's when they're trying to let me win. I'm trash at table tennis, so I was unsurprised when I sucked at Eleven. But I sucked for all the right reasons. The paddles felt right, the ball felt properly bouncy, the physics felt good. When I hit a ball straight in the air rather than across the table because I had my paddle at the wrong angle, it performed exactly as I expected it to. When I lost 11-1 to the Easiest AI, I felt like I was losing for the right reasons. Because I am trash at ping pong, and I probably always will be.

The multiplayer works, the environments are varied, the AI seems good, and the menu system is easy to navigate. There's no reason not to get this game unless you're as bad at ping pong as I am.
